briefing.opening: Good morning. We will now begin the climate briefing for January 27, 2026. Today's news will cover warnings about the escalating global climate crisis, active efforts both domestically and internationally towards carbon neutrality and renewable energy transition, and the diverse voices of the international community surrounding climate change response.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ The Climate Crisis Becomes More Urgent: Global Warnings and Deepening Impacts
sections.content: The 'Doomsday Clock,' announced today, has moved closer to midnight amidst threats from nuclear weapons, climate change, and artificial intelligence (AI), once again warning of the severe crisis humanity faces [38, 47, 65, 67]. The direct impacts of climate change are already a reality: California's iconic Highway 1 is struggling in its battle against climate change [44], and Winter Olympics snowmakers are facing difficulties due to rising temperatures [46, 52, 69]. Furthermore, an analysis indicates that the cost of climate change has nearly doubled due to ocean damage [56]. Extreme weather phenomena are being reported across the globe, including Australia facing record heatwaves and large wildfires, and nearly uncontrollable wildfires spreading in Patagonia [71, 73, 75].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Domestic and International Efforts for Carbon Neutrality
sections.content: Domestically, concrete efforts to achieve carbon neutrality are accelerating, primarily led by corporations and local governments. Hyundai Steel earned a 'Leadership' grade in the CDP Climate Change Response Assessment, moving up one level from the previous year [1], and HD Hyundai Construction Equipment recognizes 2050 carbon neutrality as a matter of 'survival, not just a slogan' [10]. Daegu City is recruiting participants for its Carbon Neutrality Point System in the energy sector [5, 14, 18], and Changwon City is investing 217.6 billion KRW in carbon neutrality initiatives, accelerating efforts in the building, transportation, and circular economy sectors [6, 13]. In the agricultural sector, carbon neutrality efforts, including 'Citrus RE100,' are gaining momentum [7, 19], and Woosung Feed is pursuing both carbon neutrality and productivity improvement simultaneously through precision feeding technology [9]. Meanwhile, in Vietnam, the SHIFT project, a green investment promotion project aimed at achieving carbon neutrality goals, has also commenced [21].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Active Movement Towards Renewable Energy Transition and Market Expansion
sections.content: Active movements towards renewable energy transition are being observed worldwide. GS E&C has made its first foray into the Indian new and renewable energy market, pursuing not only the construction and operation of solar power plants but also electricity sales [23, 27, 28, 33, 34]. The UK and the EU have agreed to jointly develop and share an exclusive offshore wind power network in the North Sea [25]. Domestically, the 'Corporate Renewable Energy Matching Day,' hosted by the Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry, saw transaction discussions for 100MW, activating the direct renewable energy trading market [30, 31, 35, 36]. Jeonnam Development Corporation and KEPCO KPS have also agreed to jointly develop wind power [32]. Furthermore, the Saemangeum floating solar power plant has been connected to the grid, opening the way for electricity supply [37], and in the European Union, the transition to eco-friendly mobility is accelerating, with electric vehicle sales surpassing gasoline car sales for the first time ever [76].

sections.title: ğŸ“° The Light and Shadow of International Awareness and Policies for Climate Change Response
sections.content: Amidst the emphasis on the need for international solidarity and increased awareness for climate change response, there is a growing perception among Americans that they are ready to act on climate change and that it is time to find collective solutions [42, 43]. The EU supported a declaration on climate change information integrity, emphasizing the importance of accurate information [45], and legislative efforts are continuing, such as a bill introduced in Maine to impose climate change responsibility on corporations [41]. However, on the other hand, former President Donald Trump showed actions that ran counter to international efforts by withdrawing the U.S. from the Paris Climate Agreement for a second time and ordering the removal of climate change and Native American-related signs in national parks [50, 51, 62, 72]. Amidst these policy contrasts, discussions on the impact of climate change on the future of trade and sustainable supply chains [57, 58], adaptation strategies such as Kenya's climate-smart food systems [59], and interesting research findings that otters can slow down climate change by eating sea urchins [60] were also reported.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing once again highlighted the severity of the global climate crisis, while also demonstrating that various stakeholders are simultaneously working to overcome the crisis. We hope that global cooperation and innovation for climate change response will continue in the future, and this concludes today's climate briefing.
